quiz.title: LA4: Analyzing Progressive Era Reform Data
quiz.description: Data Analysis Activity - Analyze historical data from the Progressive Era (1890-1920) including immigration trends, labor strikes, women's suffrage timeline, and child labor statistics. This assessment develops your data literacy skills (HTS6) while reinforcing understanding of Progressive reforms and their limitations.
linkedMLOs: MLO 1: Analyze Progressive Era reforms and their impact on democracy, labor, and social justice
MLO 3: Explain women's suffrage movement strategies and the 19th Amendment's limitations
linkedCLOs: CLO1: Analyze transformation of American society
CLO2: Evaluate how diverse groups struggled for civil rights
CLO3: Apply historical thinking skills to interpret sources
qmStandards: 3.3: Specific and descriptive criteria for evaluation
5.1: Learning activities promote achievement of objectives

stimulus.description: Students view immigration data, labor strike data, and suffrage timeline before answering questions

charts.title: Women's Suffrage by State (Before 19th Amendment)
charts.note: Southern and Eastern states did not grant suffrage until federal amendment

data.1900: 1.75 million children under 16 employed in industrial work

questions.question: According to the immigration data, what year saw PEAK immigration to the United States before World War I?

answers.text: 1907, with 1,285,000 immigrants
1890, with 455,000 immigrants
1915, with 430,000 immigrants
1900, with 800,000 immigrants

feedback.correct: Correct! 1907 marked peak immigration at 1,285,000 - nearly triple the 1890 level. The Panic of 1907 and later WWI (1914) caused sharp declines.
feedback.incorrect: Look at the immigration data line chart. Find the highest point on the graph and its corresponding year.

questions.question: Based on the immigration data, immigration declined sharply after 1907. Select ALL factors that contributed to this decline. (Select all that apply)

answers.text: The Panic of 1907 (economic recession) reduced job opportunities
Growing restrictions on immigration through legislation
World War I disrupted Atlantic travel beginning in 1914
Immigration was completely banned by federal law in 1908

feedback.correct: Correct! Multiple factors converged: economic recession (1907), increasing restrictions (literacy tests, head taxes), and WWI (1914) disrupting ocean travel all contributed to declining immigration.
feedback.incorrect: Immigration was not completely banned in 1908. Consider economic, legislative, and international factors that might have reduced immigration after 1907.

questions.question: Based on the suffrage timeline, place these states/events in chronological order by when women gained voting rights (earliest to latest).

items.text: Utah and Idaho grant women's suffrage
Washington and California grant women's suffrage

questions.feedback: Western states led the suffrage movement: Wyoming (1890), Colorado (1893), Utah/Idaho (1896). Eastern and especially Southern states resisted until forced by the 19th Amendment (1920).

questions.question: The suffrage data shows Western states granted women's suffrage decades before Eastern and Southern states. Categorize each factor as explaining WESTERN SUPPORT or EASTERN/SOUTHERN RESISTANCE to women's suffrage.

items.text: Frontier societies had fewer established gender hierarchies
Entrenched political machines opposed new voters they couldn't control
Suffrage seen as way to attract female settlers and promote 'civilization'
Fear that women's suffrage would lead to Black women voting in the South
Smaller populations made it easier to experiment with reforms
Traditional gender roles more deeply embedded in established society

questions.feedback: Regional differences in suffrage reflected broader patterns: Western progressivism and experimentation vs. Eastern machine politics and Southern racial anxieties about expanding the electorate.

questions.question: According to the labor strike data, how many MORE strikes occurred in 1904 compared to 1890?

answers.text: 2,550 more strikes
1,900 more strikes
4,450 more strikes
3,200 more strikes

feedback.correct: Correct! 4,450 - 1,900 = 2,550 more strikes. This represents a 134% increase, demonstrating growing worker militancy during the Progressive Era.
feedback.incorrect: Calculate: Strikes in 1904 (4,450) minus Strikes in 1890 (1,900) = 2,550

questions.question: The labor strike data shows strikes more than doubled from 1,900 (1890) to 4,450 (1904). What does this pattern suggest about worker conditions during industrialization?

answers.text: Workers were increasingly dissatisfied with wages, hours, and conditions, leading to more organized resistance
Workers were completely satisfied but struck to support their employers
The government encouraged strikes as official policy
Strike numbers declined as conditions improved

feedback.correct: Correct! Rising strikes reflected worker discontent with industrial conditions: long hours (10-12 hour days), dangerous workplaces, low wages, and lack of job security. Unions like the AFL organized this resistance.
feedback.incorrect: More strikes generally indicate more worker grievances, not satisfaction. Consider what conditions might motivate workers to strike.

questions.question: Match each Progressive Era reform issue with the data point that BEST illustrates the need for that reform.

items.right: 1.75 million children under 16 working in industry (1900)
30-year gap between first state (1890) and federal amendment (1920)

questions.feedback: Progressives used data and statistics to document social problems and build support for reforms. Muckraking journalists and reformers gathered evidence like these statistics to advocate for change.

questions.question: The child labor data shows 1.75 million children working in 1900. Select ALL conclusions historians can draw from this statistic about Progressive Era reform. (Select all that apply)

answers.text: Despite reform efforts, child labor remained widespread at the turn of the century
Industrial capitalism relied heavily on cheap child labor
Progressive child labor laws had limited success in the early period
Child labor was completely eliminated by 1900

feedback.correct: Correct! The 1.75 million figure shows child labor's persistence despite early reform efforts. Effective federal child labor regulation didn't come until the 1930s (Fair Labor Standards Act).
feedback.incorrect: The data shows 1.75 million children WERE working in 1900, not that child labor had been eliminated. What does this high number suggest about the effectiveness of early reforms?

questions.question: Analyzing the immigration and strike data together reveals connections. Categorize each statement as SUPPORTED or NOT SUPPORTED by the data.

items.text: Immigration and strike numbers both increased during the same period (1890-1904)
Immigrant workers often participated in labor strikes
Rising immigration coincided with industrial expansion and worker unrest
Native-born workers never participated in strikes
Both trends reflect the rapid industrialization transforming American society

questions.feedback: Immigration and strikes both increased during industrial expansion. Many immigrant workers (despite facing nativism) participated in labor movements, though they also sometimes served as strikebreakers.

questions.question: Considering all the data together, what does the evidence reveal about the LIMITATIONS of Progressive Era reforms?

answers.text: Reforms were often incomplete, regionally uneven, and slow to address root causes of social problems
Progressive reforms solved all social problems by 1920
The data shows no reforms were attempted during this period
Southern states led the nation in implementing Progressive reforms

feedback.correct: Correct! The data shows reforms' limits: suffrage took 30 years and excluded many women of color; 1.75 million children still worked; strikes increased as underlying conditions persisted. Progress was real but uneven and incomplete.
feedback.incorrect: Consider what the data reveals about the pace and completeness of reform. Did all regions embrace reform equally? Were problems solved quickly or did they persist?
